headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Will Lyons please go ahead.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our first quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO. Last night after market close, we distributed and filed our Q1 earnings release. We
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our first quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO. Last night after market close, we distributed and filed our Q1 earnings release. We filed our 10-Q, and we made available our prepared remarks on our Investor Relations website located at ir.tripadvisor.com. In the release, you will find reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP financial measures discussed on this call. Also, our IR site contains a supplemental file information documents, which include certain non-GAAP financial measures discussed on this call as well as other performance metrics. 
Instead of reading our prepared remarks on this call, Steve will jump into a couple of thoughts, and then we'll jump right into Q&A. 
Before we begin I'd like to remind you that this call may contain estimates and other forward-looking statements that represent the company's view as of today, May 10, 2017. TripAdvisor disclaims any obligation to update these statements to reflect future events or circumstances. Please refer to our earnings release and our filings with the SEC for information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. 
And with that, I'll pass the call over to Steve.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully you've had a chance to read our prepared remarks that we published last night after market close. I'll summarize by saying that 2017 is off to a productive start. In ho
componenttext:
Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully you've had a chance to read our prepared remarks that we published last night after market close. I'll summarize by saying that 2017 is off to a productive start. In hotels, we are rapidly aligning products, supply and marketing is what drive towards long-term growth and profitability. In a few weeks, we will rollout our streamlined hotel shopping experience, and soon thereafter, we'll launch our new brand advertising campaign, leveraging our strong global brand to build user awareness of TripAdvisor as a great place to find the lowest prices when you are ready to book. 
In non-hotels our continued strong demand growth in supply investments are really starting to payoff. And while focus remains our top line growth, this segment is already beginning to exhibit attractive profit potential. 
We are addressing large growth opportunities ahead and making great progress building end-to-end products that travelers love, a bigger and better platform for advertisers and a bigger and better business over the long term. Ernst?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, good morning, everyone. We saw strong growth recovery as the first quarter consolidated total revenue growth improved to 6% year-over-year or 7% in constant currency. This revenue growth also improved from our fourth quarter results, driven
componenttext: Thanks, Steve, good morning, everyone. We saw strong growth recovery as the first quarter consolidated total revenue growth improved to 6% year-over-year or 7% in constant currency. This revenue growth also improved from our fourth quarter results, driven by improvements in our TripAdvisor branded click-based transaction business. We are encouraged by the significant recovery we saw in this click-based and transaction revenue growth over the past few quarters and the continued strong growth of our non-hotel segment. Notably, we reiterate our revenue and adjusted EBITDA outlook now inclusive of our brand advertising investment. We are able to maintain this outlook by reallocating some less efficient online marketing dollars, as well as expected profit favorability in our non-hotel segment towards our brand advertising. With that, we'll now open the call for your questions.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Ross Sandler with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Ross Sandler with Barclays.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Steve, I guess the first question is just could we get a little more color on what's driving the improvement in revenue per shopper in the U.S. market? Is it coverage? Is it better competition in the auction? Any color there would be helpful. And then can
componenttext: Steve, I guess the first question is just could we get a little more color on what's driving the improvement in revenue per shopper in the U.S. market? Is it coverage? Is it better competition in the auction? Any color there would be helpful. And then can you also talk about overall engagement? As you've been making these changes to the mobile experience and as you see hotel shopper growth picked back up, what's happening with the engagement, meaning is the session frequency or visits per hotel shopper also going up? Any color there would be helpful.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So with regard to our revenue per shopper growth in the U.S., the biggest factor is certainly going to be the lapping of the Instant Book. We have made a big bet in that category, built a really nice product. But it did have some dilutive effects. N
componenttext: Sure. So with regard to our revenue per shopper growth in the U.S., the biggest factor is certainly going to be the lapping of the Instant Book. We have made a big bet in that category, built a really nice product. But it did have some dilutive effects. Now we're at a really good spot where we can -- where we have turned the team towards the regular optimization efforts that we normally go through, and we're seeing results. Simultaneously as we indicated,  we're working on our new shopping experience. And any time that we focus on delivering a better overall experience, we would look to one of the measurements being an increased revenue per shopper. When it comes to mobile, we've certainly seen meaningful growth aligned with the industry as users tip over to be using mobile apps and web. And we've seen, on our own side, improved revenue per session from users using our mobile app. I don't have specific numbers I can share in terms of increased engagements to your specific question, but suffice to say, more and more users, more and more of the time, are using our apps for, not only hotel shopping, but for the full trip.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. If I could ask one more follow-up for Ernst on non-hotel segment. So you mentioned in the prepared remarks that you expect positive EBITDA for the 2017. So can you talk about like where that margin might be exiting '17 and remind us again what long
componenttext: Great. If I could ask one more follow-up for Ernst on non-hotel segment. So you mentioned in the prepared remarks that you expect positive EBITDA for the 2017. So can you talk about like where that margin might be exiting '17 and remind us again what longer-term margin profile for non-Hotel looks like.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: We've always described this as a multi-year process in which we would initially invest in the non-hotel segment and then gradually turn it to profitability as we saw more scale in the business. We've been focused on building scale. This is the year where
componenttext: We've always described this as a multi-year process in which we would initially invest in the non-hotel segment and then gradually turn it to profitability as we saw more scale in the business. We've been focused on building scale. This is the year where we're seeing some of the building scale come to fruition in terms of leverage on the bottom line. And as we say, we expect that this non-hotel segment, in aggregate, to be EBITDA positive, which we think is a great midpoint in our journey. As we go forward, we expect our margins in the longer run to be robust and attractive. We are not managing to a particular margin. We continue to see this business as a growth and investment business. But this year, we are going to see that profitability come through. And a little faster than we even thought 3 months ago. The first quarter has seen very robust results on the top line versus expectations, but also on the bottom line versus our expectations we're seeing some efficiencies come through in this business. So positive EBITDA for the year and a strong outlook for the future.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: To add just a tiny bit of additional color to that, we're pleased to note that in our Attractions business, specifically the TripAdvisor as a demand channel is growing faster than we had anticipated. And that was, of course, one of the big pieces of syner
componenttext: To add just a tiny bit of additional color to that, we're pleased to note that in our Attractions business, specifically the TripAdvisor as a demand channel is growing faster than we had anticipated. And that was, of course, one of the big pieces of synergy that we were looking for when picking up the Viator business and all that supply had we better monetize all of the demand that's already sitting on TripAdvisor. And so on that Trip platform, demand continues to grow quite quickly, and we're able to merchandise it better having all the great Viator supply out of our fingertips.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Maybe 2 also around the marketing theme. In decommissioning inefficient spend and redeploying that money in the brand advertising, I'm curious what you think that does for return on your marketing dollars long-term for the business. That will be #1. And #
componenttext: Maybe 2 also around the marketing theme. In decommissioning inefficient spend and redeploying that money in the brand advertising, I'm curious what you think that does for return on your marketing dollars long-term for the business. That will be #1. And #2, as you do sort of decommission inefficient spend and redeploying new brand, anything we should be aware of in the quarter-to-quarter cadence of marketing that might book some of the usual seasonality trends of marketing.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric. In terms of long-term efficiency profile of our paid marketing spend, we expect from TV to create much more lifetime value of users that we acquire and influence from TV than we are going to be able to get with online marketing. So where
componenttext: Thank you, Eric. In terms of long-term efficiency profile of our paid marketing spend, we expect from TV to create much more lifetime value of users that we acquire and influence from TV than we are going to be able to get with online marketing. So where online marketing we have managed to pretty short-term roughly breakeven as a channel, the ongoing benefit is more limited and difficult to prove. With TV, with a real shift of brand perception as TripAdvisor from a place just to use for planning to use for planning plus price comparison and booking, we can get much more lasting impact on our user group. And therefore, over time, that should actually benefit our marketing efficiency profile. In terms of the seasonality of marketing spend cadence, not so much. I mean the marketing will still be aligned very much to the seasonality of the business, which doesn't change by doing advertising.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Mark May with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Mark May with Citi.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions, somewhat related, kind of have to do with the near-term risks. You're going to be reallocating a pretty significant amount of your online marketing spend. How confident are you that you've kind of had around the negative impact if that
componenttext: I have 2 questions, somewhat related, kind of have to do with the near-term risks. You're going to be reallocating a pretty significant amount of your online marketing spend. How confident are you that you've kind of had around the negative impact if that's going to have to the top line, at least in the near term? And then you will be changing your UI, it sounds like as well, how confident are you around modeling the short-term potential negative impacts? And I guess, the question there would be also, what do you see as some of the near-term potential negative impacts from the UI change?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. This is Ernst. I'll take the first question on the marketing, and Steve will take the product question. It is true that if we reallocate marketing dollars from online to TV is you get a positive impact in revenue on TV and potentially a negative imp
componenttext: Okay. This is Ernst. I'll take the first question on the marketing, and Steve will take the product question. It is true that if we reallocate marketing dollars from online to TV is you get a positive impact in revenue on TV and potentially a negative impact on online. We have done a bit of work over the last 3 months in studying different markets that we're going to dealing with TV, studying our historical patterns of impact of TV that we have found. And although there is some volatility around the results there, we feel good about the projections that we're making and good about reiterating this double-digit growth this year on our transaction-based business for TripAdvisor. Steve?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. And with regard to the user interface, we are fortunate this is the type of change that's mostly internal to TripAdvisor is not requiring a lot of assistance or behavior change on the part of our clients. So we're in control over the testing methodol
componenttext: Yes. And with regard to the user interface, we are fortunate this is the type of change that's mostly internal to TripAdvisor is not requiring a lot of assistance or behavior change on the part of our clients. So we're in control over the testing methodology, the rollout. You can see some of the changes already on the site or some of the changes already on the app, depending -- basically depending if you get lucky enough to see it. But all of that goes into our testing and how they are able to gain confidence that is, in fact, revenue neutral or revenue positive as we move to rollout. I'm not saying we wouldn't rollout completely, if we were up or down by a little bit, but we do have a lot of capabilities and are experiencing this day-to-day in tuning and tweaking the design so that it delivers not only better experience, but the revenue expectations that we have in our plan.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: In the script, you guys mentioned that absolute U.S. revenue per hotel shopper has fully recovered to levels to prior to Instant Book launch. It looked like by our math that the desktop RevPAR shopper still about 20% of the highs. Is the delta just intern
componenttext: In the script, you guys mentioned that absolute U.S. revenue per hotel shopper has fully recovered to levels to prior to Instant Book launch. It looked like by our math that the desktop RevPAR shopper still about 20% of the highs. Is the delta just international? And is that falling as similar path to the U.S. in terms of improvement? And then just following up on some of the TV questions. It's always a challenge to change user behavior. And you guys have been working at it on the IP side. I guess, what is it about the no campaign and/or the new page that makes you feel more confident you can really get users to come back closer to time approaches. Is there anything just from the test you've seen in the new page design that gives you that incremental confidence?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Lloyd, I'll take the first one, and Steve will take a second. The comment about RPS being back to 2014 levels pertain to the U.S. And so we have seen that into the U.S., internationally we have not yet seen that. And so that was a clarification I want to
componenttext: Lloyd, I'll take the first one, and Steve will take a second. The comment about RPS being back to 2014 levels pertain to the U.S. And so we have seen that into the U.S., internationally we have not yet seen that. And so that was a clarification I want to make on that point.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: And in terms of TV changing behavior, there are many examples out there where a brand in a category comes up with, you can call it, line extension if you want. So we all think back to Amazon that started at books and now did books and music, and books, mu
componenttext: And in terms of TV changing behavior, there are many examples out there where a brand in a category comes up with, you can call it, line extension if you want. So we all think back to Amazon that started at books and now did books and music, and books, music and of course, now they do everything, and they were able to do that because they have positioned themselves as a shopping site. Well, TripAdvisor is a travel site. You come to plan your trip. So we have the credibility to be able to play in the number of different aspects in that travel planning. But I couldn't go that we wouldn't be able to sell you a pair of shoes, that's kind of not what people associate TripAdvisor. So it comes from the strength reviews, as Amazon had come from a strength books, but it's well within what users are using the site for to extend it to something else. And in our case, moving into that price comparison. So we have a large portion of our current audience and have, for the past decade, come to TripAdvisor, read reviews and move into our price comparison engine and then click off to our partners, so use Instant Book to book. So that's an already established behavior pattern for a large portion of our users.  Our challenge isn't, "Hey, is that even possible? Will users do that sort of thing?" They do it. It's a huge business for us. The question is, can the TV campaign accelerate the move of the people who don't currently use us for that to join sort of the crowd that does. And a lot of people, when we ask will say, "Yes, I use it for reviews. I didn't know that you have a price comparison." And, of course, I hear that, and I think how could you miss that on our site? Oh my goodness, it's all over the place. But you have to accept what users are telling you. When we go on TV and we talk very clearly about price comparison, find the lowest price, help save you some money as a traveler. And we repeat that TV ad numerous times, we hope to educate that individual that the site that they already know and love can now be used for this new part of the hotel shopping experience, which they are already on TripAdvisor for. So we don't view it as a big leap or a big change. And when we look at our last TV campaign, it was focus less around the benefit of comparing prices and more teaching about teaching users specifically that they can now book on TripAdvisor. So we've tweaked that message, we'll be back out to the marketplace at a heavier weight with a more streamlined user experience that's focused around that hotel shopping. Think of it as less distractions on the page, more point how can we help you save some money in your shopping experience, how can we give you the best value for the hotel that you're looking for, not just the highest rated, but the best rated in your price point, those sorts of things. And we're giving ourselves time to make that message sink in through things like TV and any other online campaigns. So I view our past TV as very instructive, useful lessons to get us to where we are now, but we have a very compelling plan to achieve these objectives that we have in front of us now.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Justin Patterson with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Justin Patterson with Raymond James.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Steve, I know in the past you've often referred to TripAdvisor as being indifferent between [indiscernible] and  Instant Booking. With the new hotel shopping experience rolling out, and can you just characterize what if anything has changed within there?
componenttext: Steve, I know in the past you've often referred to TripAdvisor as being indifferent between [indiscernible] and  Instant Booking. With the new hotel shopping experience rolling out, and can you just characterize what if anything has changed within there? And then secondly, one for Ernst. On click-based transaction revenue, you mentioned that international growth rates are still significantly lagging due to constant currency. You obviously had a strong quarter with the U.S. But how should we think about the cadence of improvement in that international growth rates? And is there any reason that, that should improve at a different rate than the U.S.?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. Justin, I'll take the first part. So we look at meta and IB as 2 different methods to allow user to find, book the hotel that they want. They are on our site, they're getting the best value that they can in the sort, they're looking at the photos,
componenttext: Great. Justin, I'll take the first part. So we look at meta and IB as 2 different methods to allow user to find, book the hotel that they want. They are on our site, they're getting the best value that they can in the sort, they're looking at the photos, reading the reviews, building the confidence that they are getting the right hotel. Now the next thing the consumer absolutely needs is to get the best deal on that hotel. And so part of the new shopping experience helps pull people down that funnel of putting in your dates and actually getting to see our prices, and noting that we've scoured the web and found you a great price. The thing that's not new in this quarter or in this new design is where Instant Book fits into that mix, because we have been talking for several quarters about Instant Booking earning its position in our hotel shopping experience so that we put it in front of users when we think they are most likely use it, either for price, because Instant Book might have the best price or convenience, particularly on the phone, if it's something you've used before. So we want to build that great shopping experience. Instant Booking is a clear tool that help us do that and is a way that we can get better pricing in front of our consumers and make it more convenient, especially on the phone. But as we look forward in 2017, '18, if Instant Book -- if as some people [indiscernible] well, Instant Book is not as prominent as it once was, and that's because our customers are telling us they are indifferent as to whether they are choosing to use it versus something else, and that's okay with us, tends the comment on indifferent. We want to do what's best for our travelers, and we believe that Instant Book plays a key role in that, though not as a big a role as we had anticipated a couple of years ago.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then just in your question about the click-based revenue and any international component of that. So the U.S. is roughly half of our revenues and the other half is outside of the U.S. The U.K. is our largest market, but it's a long tail of many, many
componenttext: And then just in your question about the click-based revenue and any international component of that. So the U.S. is roughly half of our revenues and the other half is outside of the U.S. The U.K. is our largest market, but it's a long tail of many, many market internationally. Part of the differential in growth rates is attributable to timing in IB and lapping of IB, but that's not the full story. Currency is one of the factors. If you compare, for instance, the pound, the U.K. being our largest non-U.S. markets a year ago versus today. And then the mobile shift has tended to happen faster outside of the U.S. than in the U.S. And then there are many market-by-market differences. But generally, the overall market, the robustness of our auction, the level of competition is more favorable in the U.S. than in many places outside of the U.S. And so our anticipation is that the U.S. will remain the pace car in terms of growth in the foreseeable future that we believe that in the long-term international markets can be robust growers for us. And 2, with pattern we'll be -- the pattern of growth recovery is likely to be a little slower than we've seen in the U.S., and therefore, lag the U.S. more than just the lagging of the IB rollout.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions, please. First, how much is the ability to maintain your EBITDA guidance for the year as a result of the reallocation of marketing funds versus the better profitability in the non-hotel segment? I'd assume it's nearly all the reallocati
componenttext: I have 2 questions, please. First, how much is the ability to maintain your EBITDA guidance for the year as a result of the reallocation of marketing funds versus the better profitability in the non-hotel segment? I'd assume it's nearly all the reallocation of marketing dollars, but, first of all is that correct? And then second, I just -- I guess, following the previous question, assuming IB continues to be less of a focus, how do you envision navigating the challenge of the hand for mobile that IB was meant to help, or is that handoff first maybe just not as a significant of an issue as you perceive it to be as the mobile mix grow?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. We're not breaking down in more detail where the EBITDA favorability comes from to offset the TV unfavorability. But we called out these 2 factors for a reasons. They are both meaningful contributors to that. And so it's not only one or t
componenttext: Thank you, Mike. We're not breaking down in more detail where the EBITDA favorability comes from to offset the TV unfavorability. But we called out these 2 factors for a reasons. They are both meaningful contributors to that. And so it's not only one or the other we call these 2 up because they are both relevant.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: And with respect to Instant Book on the phone, if you look back, I keep talking about building the great shopping experience for hotel shoppers on the phone. And there is a click-off model that works quite well for us and others, but they're certainly a w
componenttext: And with respect to Instant Book on the phone, if you look back, I keep talking about building the great shopping experience for hotel shoppers on the phone. And there is a click-off model that works quite well for us and others, but they're certainly a wonderful convenience of being able to certain essentially buy it with a single click as sites like Amazon have shown. We don't see a reason why people won't be able to get there in the hotel space. And to do that, you need something that kind of looks like Instant Book or something pretty close. So if we fast-forward to the time when Instant Book really does have the best pricing available on the web, it's kind of matched the lowest price from anywhere, there is going to be in our prediction a set of travelers who love the TripAdvisor hotel shopping experience, they put in their credit cards and have now formed up a habit, where they are a frequent repeat user of our apps because it's just simpler and you always get the lowest price. We're not forcing that on people to be clear right now, but we see that as a wonderful endgame as the world moves to mobile. And if you're using us for price comparison, there isn't an obvious benefit of clicking out versus continuing your purchase on our site, unless someone else gives you the better price. And that's the challenge for the Instant Book team is always making sure that piece of the product has the best price. When we do that, we'll earn more than our fair share, more convenience. Where we don't, our business funnel says, will help the customers save the dollar by clicking them off to wherever does have the lowest price.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Barry Gold with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Barry Gold with MoffettNathanson.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can you provide any more color on the recently announced [indiscernible] deal? How broadly will it be rolled out? In TripAdvisor, how will it be promoted? And how should we think about the revenue opportunity longer term?
componenttext: Can you provide any more color on the recently announced [indiscernible] deal? How broadly will it be rolled out? In TripAdvisor, how will it be promoted? And how should we think about the revenue opportunity longer term?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as you know, we have a massive number of restaurants on the site globally. And folks, when they are looking for that place to eat, sometimes want to make reservation if it's a restaurant that takes reservation electronically, often want to [indis
componenttext: Sure. So as you know, we have a massive number of restaurants on the site globally. And folks, when they are looking for that place to eat, sometimes want to make reservation if it's a restaurant that takes reservation electronically, often want to [indiscernible] to refuse, look at the photos and sometimes want to do take-out order the food delivery. Grub hub is a great partner. It covers many cities, not all cities in the world. And so you can, presuming that works well for us, you'd expect to see additional food delivery platforms coming online. I'd caution against viewing that as a move the needle revenue opportunity for us as our traffic certainly tends to be reasonable mix of tourists and locals, and tourists are going to be less likely to use a food delivery service. But based upon the skill of a restaurant space, it's kind of yet another products in the mix.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Kevin Nobleman with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Kevin Nobleman with Cowen and Company.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Could you give us any color on what you're seeing in April, especially with the Easter timing comp? And then on that, you also advised against extrapolating Q1 RPS growth into Q2. Can you give any more color on why you're more cautious on that?
componenttext: Could you give us any color on what you're seeing in April, especially with the Easter timing comp? And then on that, you also advised against extrapolating Q1 RPS growth into Q2. Can you give any more color on why you're more cautious on that?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Kevin. In our prepared remarks, we didn't call out any specific comments about April, but we did comment more broadly about extrapolation from Q1 into Q2, as you point out. And we caution against extrapolating some of the graphs that we put i
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Kevin. In our prepared remarks, we didn't call out any specific comments about April, but we did comment more broadly about extrapolation from Q1 into Q2, as you point out. And we caution against extrapolating some of the graphs that we put into our prepared remarks into Q2. Q1 was, as we said in the prepared remarks as well, was a quarter whereas our year-on-year comps are paid in marketing investment were relatively favorable. So we saw an ability to significantly grow our paid revenue line in Q1, which may not translate directly into Q2. And I'll make the point more generally as some of these graphs that we put in RPS and shoppers, if you look at the last few quarters and you could be tempted to just draw a straight line into some of those curves. I just want to make sure although we have reiterated our expectation that we'll have double-digit growth in the click-based line, this year and we feel very good about where we are and we feel good about our outlook there. The quarter-to-quarter progression maybe not as smooth as some of the graphs have shown so far.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Jed Tammy with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Jed Tammy with Oppenheimer.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: On capital allocation, you continue to churn out a decent amount of free cash flow and have the second consecutive quarter of decent buybacks activity. Can you share your managing buybacks versus acquisitions versus investing for growth? And just giving y
componenttext: On capital allocation, you continue to churn out a decent amount of free cash flow and have the second consecutive quarter of decent buybacks activity. Can you share your managing buybacks versus acquisitions versus investing for growth? And just giving your comments around the long-term outlook for the business when stock is currently trading, would it makes sense to be the more aggressive around the buybacks?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. In deed, we put $150 million to work in Q1 for share repurchases at an average price of $42.49. we -- and also underlined what you said in your opening statement is that we are indeed generating significant cash flows just from op
componenttext: Thanks for the question. In deed, we put $150 million to work in Q1 for share repurchases at an average price of $42.49. we -- and also underlined what you said in your opening statement is that we are indeed generating significant cash flows just from operations. As we think about allocation, the areas of where we could invest outside of the business, outside of the operations of the business is M&A as evidenced in the last few years and the acquisitions that we've made like Viator, like Ford LaFourchette. Last year, we made a number of smaller investments, but a number of investments there as well. And we'll continue to look at opportunities that may present itself in the M&A space. And then there's share repurchase as an opportunity as well. And as you say, we clearly, in 2016 and in the first quarter of 2017, have seen an opportunity to buy back some of our shares. The program is reviewed by the Board from time to time in January. The Board approved refreshing the $250 million allocation that we had for share repurchases. And we have a 10b5 program in place with different triggers that we don't want to go into detail. But they resulted in purchasing in Q1, and from time to time will allow us to benefit from peers where we, I believe, our share prices is attractive as an acquisition -- of ourselves, of our own stock.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can you guys help us understand how much of the recovery and the return to the pre-IB monetization levels that you're seeing in the U.S. is coming from optimizing on Instant Book versus shifting back to meta? And then also just wanted to follow-up on mobi
componenttext: Can you guys help us understand how much of the recovery and the return to the pre-IB monetization levels that you're seeing in the U.S. is coming from optimizing on Instant Book versus shifting back to meta? And then also just wanted to follow-up on mobile. Can you just talk about what the mobile to desktop monetization gap is you're currently and your comments on extrapolating the same rational, Ernst, that you mentioned a few minutes ago?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the U.S., I think it's a little bit difficult to untangle after so many years of how much the RPS is, is this or the other. I do want to comment that we made continuous improvements on the revenue per shopper on desktop and  in mobile. And in the
componenttext: Yes. So the U.S., I think it's a little bit difficult to untangle after so many years of how much the RPS is, is this or the other. I do want to comment that we made continuous improvements on the revenue per shopper on desktop and  in mobile. And in the U.S., we've been able to do that and we've been making continuous improvements on Instant Bookings. We send a few quarters ago already that we, in the U.S., Instant Booking was no longer dilutive to the overall offering, and we've been improving both meta and IB since then. So I think it's a combination of factors, but it's just a sign that after incorporating -- fully incorporating in some booking in the U.S. now we're off we are no better off than we were in '14 and we continue to show impressive growth to our revenue per shopper. In terms of the desktop monetization gap, we said in the past, if mobile monetizes roughly at 1/3 of desktop and those trends change a little quarter-over-quarter, but not dramatically, we saw a quarter in the first quarter where there was revenue per shopper improvements on mobile and we had 35%, about 35% growth of our phone the revenues and about 25% growth on the shopper line. And so we're very pleased with that, and we continue to plug away making sure that we make that gap as small as we can. And in terms of your last question it's about the Q2. Again with mobile as with the general comments I was making quarter-to-quarter, there may be some volatility in revenue per shopper or in monetization of mobile, but the long-term trend is pretty stable.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line with Heath Terry of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line with Heath Terry of Goldman Sachs.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Daniel Powell on for Heath. Just a couple of quick ones from us. First on the traffic growth and comments you've made around paid acquisition, just curious if you could give any comments on what you're actually see in organic search and how much o
componenttext: This is Daniel Powell on for Heath. Just a couple of quick ones from us. First on the traffic growth and comments you've made around paid acquisition, just curious if you could give any comments on what you're actually see in organic search and how much of that is coloring your decision to lean more into paid acquisition? And then on the non-Hotel side, I just want to make sure we're interpreting our comments are there correctly about approaching 2016 growth levels, maybe suggesting acceleration in the back half of the year against some tougher comps. Is that driven by seasonality mostly or is there something else that changed the business?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dino, for the question. This is Steve. So I wouldn't say there's anything particularly different in our organic search trends. Google continues to take more space on search result pages on all devices for their own products and for other paid ads.
componenttext: Thanks, Dino, for the question. This is Steve. So I wouldn't say there's anything particularly different in our organic search trends. Google continues to take more space on search result pages on all devices for their own products and for other paid ads. There's nothing new in that statements, I've been say something like it for several years now. When we look at our overall marketing mix, we have more and more sort of brand traffic, we have paid traffic, we have of organic traffic, we have our CRM program and our focus at this point is on building what we call that branded direct traffic, focused with an offline TV campaign in order to build more brand direct, build more loyalty to trip when a user is in mind for shopping. So I wouldn't say it's that shift is any result of any -- it is not a result of any specific organic search trend, but it is a change for our us and it's -- we view a pretty meaningful one in terms of building the business for the long-term on large component of brand direct channels.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: In terms of the non-Hotel, it is indeed a very seasonal business. And even the growth is somewhat seasonal. Last year in the first quarter, we posted, from memory, I believe, 14% growth for non-Hotel, which was substantially lower than the rest of the yea
componenttext: In terms of the non-Hotel, it is indeed a very seasonal business. And even the growth is somewhat seasonal. Last year in the first quarter, we posted, from memory, I believe, 14% growth for non-Hotel, which was substantially lower than the rest of the year. And indeed, we said in our prepared remarks that we expect for the full year on hotel growth will be approaching the levels that we have for the full year of last year so implied in that they indeed and is that we expect growth to be better in the rest of the year than the first quarter. Other than underlying some of the seasonality we've seen in Vacation Rentals for instance, a continued shift free-to-list model, which means we get paid on booking, which tends to happen in the summer rather than early on, rather than at the time of [indiscernible] or rather than just time of booking. And then there's some currency issues in there, again our Vacation Rentals, but also our Attractions business are, for a large part, pound driven and of course, we have Brexit and the adjustment to the pound happening in the second quarter of last year. So all in all, a number of factors why we believe Q1 should be a lower point compared to the full year in terms of non-Hotel growth.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Matt Schindler of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Matt Schindler of Bank of America.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Ernst just wanted to go a little more detail on the guidance and/or your profit outlook comments. You said you can maintain profit outlook comments. But at this point, your profit outlook comments are simply flat to down. That's quite, frankly, an infinit
componenttext: Ernst just wanted to go a little more detail on the guidance and/or your profit outlook comments. You said you can maintain profit outlook comments. But at this point, your profit outlook comments are simply flat to down. That's quite, frankly, an infinite range. So if I look at ROI as negative on the brand campaign, I know you're switching out assuming efficient marketing dollars we have to pay for that but there will be some revenue lift from that brand campaign is well. How much are you really thinking that sits on the relative line or you're saying that this is no impact from where you were thinking last quarter?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt. Thanks for that question. Said last quarter, we said flat to down indirect that we didn't specify what down really could imply. What we really wanted to signal with this quarter is that, that outlook does not change because of TV. And that effe
componenttext: Yes, Matt. Thanks for that question. Said last quarter, we said flat to down indirect that we didn't specify what down really could imply. What we really wanted to signal with this quarter is that, that outlook does not change because of TV. And that effectively, that negative impact on EBITDA we expect from TV, you said is ROI negative in the near term, and in the long term, we think it's very much ROI positive. But it will have a near-term drag on EBITDA just the TV campaign itself, which is offset by these 2 drivers that I talked about, partly by reallocating some of our online spend. So we look in our total portfolio of advertising spend and said, TV doesn't necessarily have to be a bolt on. We look at what does that mean for our online, and we have been allocating some expendables of the margin less efficient than the average and the located that's for his TV. And then as we highlighted, we have upgraded our outlook on profitability of our non-hotel segment. And those 2 factors together for '17 happen to be roughly equivalent to the EBITDA loss we expect from the TV campaign. So together, taken together, do not have been poorly impact on their with of the business would be famous ago was a good brand advertising campaign. And therefore, we are reiterating the same guidance flat to down that we did a quarter ago.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. And just 1 secondary question on this. Because this is happening fairly late in the year. I'm assuming that the $70 million to $80 million is smaller than you would do next year and the years after, and you mentioned a few years, this campaign will
componenttext: Great. And just 1 secondary question on this. Because this is happening fairly late in the year. I'm assuming that the $70 million to $80 million is smaller than you would do next year and the years after, and you mentioned a few years, this campaign will continue for at least a few years. Is there anything -- I give you a sending color on what you're seeing our business year on this campaign will be. And then just on another corollary to this brand campaign, you pulled back after the '14 and '15 campaigns, you pulled back of those campaigns because they didn't work as well as you hope. What makes you think that this time TV will work better?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, your observation is correct, is that the $70 million to $80 million in 2017 is starting well into the year, of course. And as such, as we look in the following years, the investment will be over a full year rather than just over a -- what is going to
componenttext: Yes, your observation is correct, is that the $70 million to $80 million in 2017 is starting well into the year, of course. And as such, as we look in the following years, the investment will be over a full year rather than just over a -- what is going to be a little bit roughly more than half a year in 2017. So that's a good observation. The additional point is that we're starting with the U.S. and a handful of other markets, not yet to the global campaign. U.S. plus a handful of markets will be of a very meaningful representation of our total revenues in these markets, of course, but not yet a global campaign. And we may add other markets as we go forward. It's a little early for us to be more specific about what our expectation is for spending 2018. We're obviously going to have more information under our belt in the next few months as we are actually rolling out advertising in these markets in and due time, we'll revisit that question on what the size would be for '18.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: And with respect to the brand campaigns that we had in '14 to '15, I thought that they were failures. They just didn't quite achieve all of the objectives that we have wanted at the time. So we're actually taking a number of the learnings from those campa
componenttext: And with respect to the brand campaigns that we had in '14 to '15, I thought that they were failures. They just didn't quite achieve all of the objectives that we have wanted at the time. So we're actually taking a number of the learnings from those campaigns and applying them. One of the learnings was, hey, we don't want to just say that you can book on TripAdvisor. We want to drive home the price point that you can find the best price on TripAdvisor. And that's more of the value orientation in the message. Then of course, the products needs to deliver that lowest-priced front and center, and a couple of years ago, it didn't. The hero price on a particular page was not necessarily the cheapest. And so we have added more supply into our store, and we changed our algorithm, so that we showing you better deals and we're showing you better prices all the time. So the product is delivery more of what our current advertising will be talking about. So you take those components, plus the learnings, and that gives us confidence that this ad campaign just literally based upon what we did learn from last time, will work for us.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next version will come from the line of Paul Bieber with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next version will come from the line of Paul Bieber with Crédit Suisse.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: I apologize if it's already been asked, but how should we generally think about the privatization of meta versus Instant Book when you launched the new user interface in the coming months?
componenttext: I apologize if it's already been asked, but how should we generally think about the privatization of meta versus Instant Book when you launched the new user interface in the coming months?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. You shouldn't think of those as necessarily connected. We've been adjusting the placement of Instant Book over the past several quarters. It's floating more, it's earning it's right based upon what consumers want to do. And that aspect does
componenttext: This is Steve. You shouldn't think of those as necessarily connected. We've been adjusting the placement of Instant Book over the past several quarters. It's floating more, it's earning it's right based upon what consumers want to do. And that aspect doesn't change as we roll out this new user interface.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up, in terms of TV ad campaign, is the intend to drive more awareness of the relative TripAdvisor brand or is it to drive awareness of the meta versus Instant Book.
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up, in terms of TV ad campaign, is the intend to drive more awareness of the relative TripAdvisor brand or is it to drive awareness of the meta versus Instant Book.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Neither. We have tremendous aided brand awareness in most countries. We're looking to drive unaided awareness of TripAdvisor as a booking site. And so many people know us just as reviews, and when they think they want to read reviews, they come to TripAdv
componenttext: Neither. We have tremendous aided brand awareness in most countries. We're looking to drive unaided awareness of TripAdvisor as a booking site. And so many people know us just as reviews, and when they think they want to read reviews, they come to TripAdvisor. They want to make sure that when they're thinking about, hey, I want to get a good deal of this hotel that I want to stay at that they come to TripAdvisor for that purpose. So again, unaided booking awareness or unaided awareness as TripAdvisor as a booking site would be the key goal of that campaign. And the campaign is completely agnostic to Instant Book versus meta. It's about booking your -- it's about [indiscernible] it's about booking the hotel.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of James B with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of James B with Mizuho Securities.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Steve, can you talk about some of the new targeting technology that you introduced the hotel search? For an example, from a couple of industry conference as side, we attended a few agency talked about your firm offering, like CRM targeting and retargeting
componenttext: Steve, can you talk about some of the new targeting technology that you introduced the hotel search? For an example, from a couple of industry conference as side, we attended a few agency talked about your firm offering, like CRM targeting and retargeting using pixels, and just curious how those technologies are performing versus your existing ones. And are you also testing maybe other technology like look-alike marketing as well on your platform?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: So I'm going to answer the question as kind of what are the targeting technologies that we offer our CPC and CPM clients to best target traffic that they want that's on our site. And so for CPM, we've kind of we have many years of dividing up audiences, l
componenttext: So I'm going to answer the question as kind of what are the targeting technologies that we offer our CPC and CPM clients to best target traffic that they want that's on our site. And so for CPM, we've kind of we have many years of dividing up audiences, luxury audiences. There is a type of a look-alike product that our sales force has been using quite successfully. When it comes to the CPC, we do offer things like retargeting pixels on our client sites so that they can be differentially on traffic that's been on their site that is now TripAdvisor, presuming that they are more attractive customer for them. They can bid up, and that's capabilities that we offered for several quarters now.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing a very meaningful lift versus other targeting technology? I'm talking to some of your peers, especially online marketing, when they start using CRM targeting, especially when it comes to search, they saw a pretty decent lift. And I'm just w
componenttext: Are you seeing a very meaningful lift versus other targeting technology? I'm talking to some of your peers, especially online marketing, when they start using CRM targeting, especially when it comes to search, they saw a pretty decent lift. And I'm just wondering from your process of working with clients, how do you see that impact?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes,  many of our clients have adopted many of the different things that we offer. You have to put it a little bit in perspective because we're familiar with retargeting capabilities as TripAdvisor advertises on other sites. And we tend to want to buy tra
componenttext: Yes,  many of our clients have adopted many of the different things that we offer. You have to put it a little bit in perspective because we're familiar with retargeting capabilities as TripAdvisor advertises on other sites. And we tend to want to buy traffic to our site that has travel intent versus buying a car or a house as a result of things. The folks that are looking to buy traffic on our site, all of our traffic is already prequalified as travel traffic. So it's already past the major hurdles. Now are looking to new ones, or our clients are looking to new ones where they're retargeting pixels over what they look like unanswered. So yes, it's valuable, but not necessarily that is which why we offered and why a lot of client use it, and you can kind infer some of that goodness in our CPC numbers from the number of bookings that we drive for our clients, but it's not the same order of magnitude that a Facebook or Google might be able to offer to their audiences.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Steve, can I also ask you a question regarding global monetization? Some of your peers have been successfully using cross device attribution because they have a lag in ID. So they can use mobile to provide the credit for desktop attribution or conversion.
componenttext: Steve, can I also ask you a question regarding global monetization? Some of your peers have been successfully using cross device attribution because they have a lag in ID. So they can use mobile to provide the credit for desktop attribution or conversion. That are doing the same thing right now internally? Just curious where you are in that process? Have you done any test at all? And have you seen any success using cross device attribution on your platform?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'd say, we like many other companies, where a majority of our revenue is not from log-in users do have a really tough time tracking that mobile attribution, that it frankly drives us a bit crazy because we qualify millions of travelers every day on our p
componenttext: I'd say, we like many other companies, where a majority of our revenue is not from log-in users do have a really tough time tracking that mobile attribution, that it frankly drives us a bit crazy because we qualify millions of travelers every day on our phone, on our app, on our website, and then send them over to our clients, and then those users come back the next day and book on desktop on a client sites, and of course, we can't track it, our clients can track it. So we don't get the credit that we deserve. That's part of that big monetization link to that we keep referring to, and that 1-day [indiscernible]  Will help us address on the phone. But, no, I can't point to any tremendous data of successes in terms of cross device attribution that we've been able to share with our clients. So still work in progress for us.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Peter Stabler with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Peter Stabler with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to the marketing, again. Apologies. You mentioned in the prepared remarks that a handful of markets overseas. Can you just give us a little more color. Are you going to go in with a similar stance in terms of weight levels and weeks or
componenttext: I wanted to go back to the marketing, again. Apologies. You mentioned in the prepared remarks that a handful of markets overseas. Can you just give us a little more color. Are you going to go in with a similar stance in terms of weight levels and weeks or is the international rollout more on a test basis? And any color you can give a sense of the coverage of your major international markets and whether the market list will likely to expand appreciably next year or even later this year.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So a handful of markets will sort of talk about the same message at the weight level that's appropriate for that market, i.e. not a small test, but a meaningful spend so that we can see results and optimize. It would be perfectly reasonable to read
componenttext: Sure. So a handful of markets will sort of talk about the same message at the weight level that's appropriate for that market, i.e. not a small test, but a meaningful spend so that we can see results and optimize. It would be perfectly reasonable to read into our comments that as we move on TV in 2018, since we're a global company, there is no logical argument that we would limit it to just a handful of markets that were in TV now you might instead read into, well we couldn't tackle all markets in the very beginning. There's simply a bandwidth question that's involved. So we think we're making a very meaningful move here, limited by our ability to execute and the desire to learn as much as we can, as quickly as we can in order to optimize for next year.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Naved Khan from Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Naved Khan from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Steve, in the past, I think you've said that you think Instant Book is a better experience for mobile monetization. Do you still hold that view or do you think that it could be either Instant Book or meta? And then I have a follow-up question on the non-H
componenttext: Steve, in the past, I think you've said that you think Instant Book is a better experience for mobile monetization. Do you still hold that view or do you think that it could be either Instant Book or meta? And then I have a follow-up question on the non-Hotel side.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: So when the Instant Book product has a parity price, then my personal opinion is it's a better product because it's fewer clicks to get what you want done. Where Instant Book has the worst price for whatever reason, we're not pushing it on you, because we
componenttext: So when the Instant Book product has a parity price, then my personal opinion is it's a better product because it's fewer clicks to get what you want done. Where Instant Book has the worst price for whatever reason, we're not pushing it on you, because we're not asking you to spend more money for the privilege of using this past. And then rubber meets the road or the questions most relevant when you have a parity price with other providers. At which point, look, some users we fully expect to be loyal to a different booking site, I think TripAdvisor for finding them the best price. That best price might be on Booking.com, and they click over to Booking.com, and they're happy with that experience, and we're fine with that, we get update on the quick and we help drive the booking. Other folks, because they're in the habit of booking on TripAdvisor, using our Instant Book with our stored credit card, we'll prefer the TripAdvisor option because it's literally fewer clicks to actually finish that booking. No need to switch. So our wealth of product capabilities here allows us to tailor the experience to what we think that individual traveler is looking for. And we think that's a great option. So Instant Book on phone, when it has the better price, it's clearly has a better experience than meta, because it saves money. But when is the worst price, you probably not going to see it a whole lot. And when the price parity, the user gets to decide, if you will, and we make our suggestion in terms of order based upon what we think the user wants to see.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then quickly on the non-Hotel side. I think, and especially on Attractions, I think as previously said, you think of this as a 3 to 5 years sort of investment opportunity, where you actually want to focus in growing the business. A
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then quickly on the non-Hotel side. I think, and especially on Attractions, I think as previously said, you think of this as a 3 to 5 years sort of investment opportunity, where you actually want to focus in growing the business. And I think we are in year 3 in 2017, and you're already looking at margins kind of turning positive. Do you think that this business is ready to see some margin expansion [indiscernible] on? How should we think about it?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, [indiscernible] correct that, we have described it as a 3 to 5-year journey, and we are in year 3, and we're seeing profits coming through this year. We have invested significant amounts of dollars in 2015 and 2016 in growing our supply. But importan
componenttext: Yes, [indiscernible] correct that, we have described it as a 3 to 5-year journey, and we are in year 3, and we're seeing profits coming through this year. We have invested significant amounts of dollars in 2015 and 2016 in growing our supply. But importantly, as a Steve noted earlier, in making all of this bookable supply also available on the TripAdvisor site where we have the most leverage in terms of exposing it to the largest number of users. And we're now seeing that flywheel of supply, getting supply on, them making it available for all of these TripAdvisor users start to work and so this is the first year where we, in aggregate, are profitable for this non-hotel segment which is a great trend and we believe in the long-term, will make the segment much a good note growing but a bit profitable segment.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes our question-and-answer session for today. I would like to hand the conference back over to Mr. Steve Kaufer Chief Executive Officer for closing comments or remarks.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, everyone, for joining the call. The first quarter 2017 was a great starting point to the year. We still have a lot of work ahead of us, but we are making progress on all of our initiatives as we build the best user experience in travel.
componenttext:
Well, thank you, everyone, for joining the call. The first quarter 2017 was a great starting point to the year. We still have a lot of work ahead of us, but we are making progress on all of our initiatives as we build the best user experience in travel. 
I want to thank our employees around the globe for their continued hard work, and we look forward to updating you on our progress next quarter. Thanks.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation on today's conference. This concludes the program, and you may all disconnect. Everybody, have a wonderful day.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to TripAdvisor's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Will Lyons. Please go ahead.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our first quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO. Last night, after market close, we distributed and filed our Q1 earnings release.
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our first quarter earnings conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO; and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO. 
Last night, after market close, we distributed and filed our Q1 earnings release. We filed our 10-Q, and we made available our prepared remarks on our Investor Relations website located at ir.tripadvisor.com. 
In the release, you'll find reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP financial measures discussed on this call. Also our IR site contains a supplemental file information document, which includes certain non-GAAP financial measures discussed on this call as well as other performance metrics. 
Instead of reading our prepared remarks on this call, Steve will jump into a couple of thoughts. And then we'll jump right into Q&A. 
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that this call may contain estimates and other forward-looking statements that represent the company's view as of today, May 10, 2017. TripAdvisor disclaims any obligation to update these statements to reflect future events or circumstances. Please refer to our earnings release and our filings with the SEC for information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. 
And with that, I'll pass the call over to Steve.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully, you've had a chance to read our prepared remarks that we published last night after market close. I'll summarize by saying 2017 is off to a productive start. In Hote
componenttext:
Thank you, Will, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining the call. Hopefully, you've had a chance to read our prepared remarks that we published last night after market close. I'll summarize by saying 2017 is off to a productive start. 
In Hotels, we're rapidly aligning products, supply and marketing as we drive towards long-term growth and profitability. In a few weeks, we will roll out our streamlined hotel shopping experience, and soon thereafter, we'll launch our new brand advertising campaign, leveraging our strong global brand to build user awareness of TripAdvisor as a great place to find the lowest prices when you are ready to book. 
In Non-hotel, our continued strong demand growth in supply investments are really starting to payoff. And while focus remains on top line growth, this segment is already beginning to exhibit attractive profit potential. 
We are addressing large growth opportunities ahead and making great progress building end-to-end products that travelers love, a bigger and better platform for advertisers and a bigger and better business over the long term. 
Ernst?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. We saw a strong growth recovery as the first quarter consolidated total revenue growth improved to 6% year-over-year or 7% in constant currency. This revenue growth also improved from our fourth quarter results,
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. We saw a strong growth recovery as the first quarter consolidated total revenue growth improved to 6% year-over-year or 7% in constant currency. This revenue growth also improved from our fourth quarter results, driven by improvements in our TripAdvisor's -- TripAdvisor-branded click-based and transaction business. We are encouraged by the significant recovery we saw in this click-based and transaction revenue growth over the past few quarters and the continued strong growth of our Non-Hotel segment. 
Notably, we reiterate our revenue and adjusted EBITDA outlook, now inclusive of our brand advertising investment. We are able to maintain this outlook by reallocating some less efficient online marketing dollars as well as expected profit favorability in our Non-Hotel segment towards our brand advertising. 
With that, we'll now open the call for your questions.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Ross Sandler with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Ross Sandler with Barclays.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Steve, I guess the first question is just could we get a little more color on what's driving the improvement in revenue per shopper in the U.S. market? Is it coverage? Is it better competition in the auction? Any color there would be helpful. And then can
componenttext: Steve, I guess the first question is just could we get a little more color on what's driving the improvement in revenue per shopper in the U.S. market? Is it coverage? Is it better competition in the auction? Any color there would be helpful. And then can you also talk about overall engagement? As you -- as you've been making these changes to the mobile experience and as you see hotel shopper growth picked back up, what's happening with the engagement? Meaning, is the session frequency or visits per hotel shopper also going up? Any color there would be helpful.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So with regard to our revenue per shopper growth in the U.S., the biggest factor is certainly going to be the lapping of Instant Book. We have made a big bet in that category, built a really nice product. But it did have some dilutive effects. So no
componenttext: Sure. So with regard to our revenue per shopper growth in the U.S., the biggest factor is certainly going to be the lapping of Instant Book. We have made a big bet in that category, built a really nice product. But it did have some dilutive effects. So now we're at a really good spot where we can -- where we have turned the team towards the regular optimization efforts that we normally go through, and we're seeing results. Simultaneously, as we indicated, we're working on our new shopping experience. And any time that we focus on delivering a better overall experience, we would look to one of the measurements being an increased revenue per shopper. When it comes to mobile, we've certainly seen meaningful growth aligned with the industry as users tip over to be using mobile apps and web. And we've seen, on our own side, an improved revenue per session from users using our mobile app. I don't have specific numbers I can share in terms of increased engagement to your specific question, but suffice to say, more and more users, more and more of the time, are using our apps for, not only hotel shopping, but with the full trip.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I can ask one more follow-up for Ernst on the Non-Hotel segment. So you mentioned in the prepared remarks that you expect positive EBITDA for the 2017. So can you talk about, like, where that margin might be exiting '17? And remind us again
componenttext: Great. And if I can ask one more follow-up for Ernst on the Non-Hotel segment. So you mentioned in the prepared remarks that you expect positive EBITDA for the 2017. So can you talk about, like, where that margin might be exiting '17? And remind us again what the longer-term margin profile for Non-Hotel looks like.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've always described this as a multi-year process in which we would initially invest in the Non-Hotel segment and then gradually turn it to profitability, as we saw more scale in the business. We've been focused on building scale. This is the year
componenttext: Yes. We've always described this as a multi-year process in which we would initially invest in the Non-Hotel segment and then gradually turn it to profitability, as we saw more scale in the business. We've been focused on building scale. This is the year where we're seeing some of that building scale come to fruition in terms of leverage on the bottom line. And as we say, we expect that this Non-Hotel segment, in aggregate, to be EBITDA positive, which, we think, is a great midpoint in our journey. As we go forward, we expect our margins over the -- in the longer run to be robust and attractive. We're not managing to a particular margin. We continue to see this business as a growth and investment business. But this year, we are going to see that profitability come through, and a little faster than we even thought 3 months ago. The first quarter has seen very robust results on the top line versus expectations, but also on the bottom line versus our expectation. We're seeing some efficiencies come through in this business. So positive EBITDA for the year and a strong outlook for the future.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
