headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to TripAdvisor's Vice President
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to TripAdvisor's Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference call over to TripAdvisor's Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Will Lyons. Please go ahead.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sonja. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO, and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO. Last night, after market closed, we distributed and filed our Q3 earnings release. We filed
componenttext:
Thanks, Sonja. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter conference call. Joining me today are Steve Kaufer, our CEO, and Ernst Teunissen, our CFO. Last night, after market closed, we distributed and filed our Q3 earnings release. We filed our 10-Q. We made available our prepared remarks on our Investor Relations website located at ir.tripadvisor.com. 
In the release, you'll find reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP financial measures discussed on this call. You'll also find supplemental financial information which includes certain non-GAAP financial measures discussed on this call as well as other performance metrics. 
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that this call may contain estimates and other forward-looking statements that represent the company's view as of today, November 7, 2017. TripAdvisor disclaims any obligation to update these statements to reflect future events or circumstances. Please refer to our earnings release and our filings with the SEC for information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. And with that, I'll pass the call over to Steve.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Will. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. As we discussed in our prepared remarks last night, we continued to make progress on our long-term growth initiatives and to building more durable direct relationships with hotel
componenttext:
Thank you, Will. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. As we discussed in our prepared remarks last night, we continued to make progress on our long-term growth initiatives and to building more durable direct relationships with hotel shoppers on our platform. Reallocating marketing dollars to brand-building channels has contributed to some of the top line results but we believe this is the best path towards driving profitable revenue growth over the long term. 
In non-Hotel, strong momentum continues, particularly in Attractions and Restaurants, products that deepen traveler engagement with our platform. We are investing to further broaden our marketplace, to grow bookable supply and to improve the product experience, helping more travelers throughout more moments of every trip. In both segments, we have a lot more work to do but we play the long game and remain focused on building for the long term. Ernst?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Reigniting our near-term hotel revenue growth has proven more challenging than we expected this quarter and this year, but our product and marketing initiatives continued to deliver early positive signs and we're
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Reigniting our near-term hotel revenue growth has proven more challenging than we expected this quarter and this year, but our product and marketing initiatives continued to deliver early positive signs and we're optimizing our marketing mix for a maximum long-term benefit. 
Our advertising investment was the primary driver of Q3 operating expense growth year-over-year. The prudent expense management as well as continued strength in our non-Hotel segment has enabled us to maintain our 2017 adjusted EBITDA expectations. Across our business, we will continue to strike an appropriate balance between growth and profitability as we aim for long-term shareholder value creation. With that, we'll open it up for your call -- for your questions.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Lloyd Walmsley of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Lloyd Walmsley of Deutsche Bank.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Two if I can. First, in the prepared remarks, you guys had said hotel shopper growth is flattish in October. So just wondering if mobile continues to hover around, say, the mid-20s range. It would imply desktop shopper growth falling double digits into Oc
componenttext: Two if I can. First, in the prepared remarks, you guys had said hotel shopper growth is flattish in October. So just wondering if mobile continues to hover around, say, the mid-20s range. It would imply desktop shopper growth falling double digits into October. Is that the right way to think about it? And then second one, on the non-Hotel side, can you give us some color on the cost structure to the business here relative maybe to the core business? Is it more advertising-intensive historically? And we asked because, obviously, you're seeing a nice margin expansion. Some of it's driven by declining OpEx year-over-year just trying to get a sense for what the cost structure looks like where it might have bottomed out such that future EBITDA will be more driven by top line growth on that side.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hi, Lloyd. Good morning. The mobile question, yes. We did see deceleration. Actually throughout Q3 and in October, we saw flattish overall shopper growth. It is a continuation of relative outperformance of mobile shopper growth and underperformance of des
componenttext: Hi, Lloyd. Good morning. The mobile question, yes. We did see deceleration. Actually throughout Q3 and in October, we saw flattish overall shopper growth. It is a continuation of relative outperformance of mobile shopper growth and underperformance of desktop shopper growth. So that's a trend that continues and it's underlying that overall trend. In terms of your second question and the cost structure between Hotel and non-Hotel, so what we see is that the cost structure is quite comparable in terms of the line items of sales and marketing, tech and content and general admin in terms of the structure of the P&L. So not that much different. What we've seen this year is scale benefits in the non-Hotel business. We're growing -- we're particularly growing faster our TripAdvisor platforms for Attractions, for instance, but also for Vacation Rentals, which has allowed us to be more inefficient with our marketing spend this year compared to other years, and its overall scale benefits actually that's driving most of the margin expansion in that segment this year.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Kopelman of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Kopelman of Cowen and Company.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can you give us -- you gave a lot of really good color on the transaction click-based and transaction-based revenue. Can you give us more color on what Q4 or the full year is looking like for non-Hotel and perhaps some of the other Hotel lines to get to t
componenttext: Can you give us -- you gave a lot of really good color on the transaction click-based and transaction-based revenue. Can you give us more color on what Q4 or the full year is looking like for non-Hotel and perhaps some of the other Hotel lines to get to that full year revenue -- new revenue guide for low-single digits growth?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hi, Kevin. The other lines see a continuation of trends more or less. The non-Hotel sees into Q4 very similar growth trends as we've seen throughout the year. Early in the year, we said we would expect similar growth in '17 as we did in '16. That sti
componenttext: Yes. Hi, Kevin. The other lines see a continuation of trends more or less. The non-Hotel sees into Q4 very similar growth trends as we've seen throughout the year. Early in the year, we said we would expect similar growth in '17 as we did in '16. That still holds. So not much movement in other lines from Q3, Q4 in terms of relative growth rate. It's really the click-based and transaction that's the big difference.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then just one follow-up on that. It looks like a very easy comp in I think other Hotel revenue. Is that, in fact, an easy comp? Or what does it look like?
componenttext: And then just one follow-up on that. It looks like a very easy comp in I think other Hotel revenue. Is that, in fact, an easy comp? Or what does it look like?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we've seen in the other Hotel revenue, we've seen deceleration, negative growth rates in the first half. We're happy to see that turn around again in Q3 again and, the trend into Q4 will be  was likely not to be too dissimilar from Q3.
componenttext: Yes. So we've seen in the other Hotel revenue, we've seen deceleration, negative growth rates in the first half. We're happy to see that turn around again in Q3 again and, the trend into Q4 will be  was likely not to be too dissimilar from Q3.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then just one final kind of big-picture question. As you plan out -- as you plan for 2018, how are you -- what are your balancing as you figure out what an appropriate level of growth and profit is? And how should we be thinking about it?
componenttext: And then just one final kind of big-picture question. As you plan out -- as you plan for 2018, how are you -- what are your balancing as you figure out what an appropriate level of growth and profit is? And how should we be thinking about it?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we think about 2018, clearly on the top line side, as we highlighted in our prepared remarks, we'll enter 2018 with the headwinds that we've seen on the top line in our core auction that we have described. So that will be a headwind moving into th
componenttext: Yes. As we think about 2018, clearly on the top line side, as we highlighted in our prepared remarks, we'll enter 2018 with the headwinds that we've seen on the top line in our core auction that we have described. So that will be a headwind moving into the New Year. We continue to think about our marketing budget as an increase of TV spend but a gradual increase of TV spend is next year but a reallocation of less efficient paid marketing spend as well. So overall, we need to balance the 2 aspects of our marketing mix. And then overall, we'll take a very prudent look at our other expenses as well in the Hotel segment. In non-Hotel, we expect continued progress on both on top and bottom and we'll continue to grow that business as we have over the last quarters and years.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Deepak Mathivanan of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Deepak Mathivanan of Barclays.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Two questions for me. So first, mobile modernization continues to improve well. I think it's up 4% this quarter while desktop, there has been a sharp decline. Can you elaborate the trends that's driving mobile, which is desktop monetization, particularly
componenttext: Two questions for me. So first, mobile modernization continues to improve well. I think it's up 4% this quarter while desktop, there has been a sharp decline. Can you elaborate the trends that's driving mobile, which is desktop monetization, particularly considering the partner spend adjustments? And then second one, just to elaborate a little bit -- maybe you can elaborate a little bit on the marketing budgets. You noted that you'll pull back from certain less efficient channels. How should we think about this corporate add going forward in 2018? Perhaps you can maybe call out what specific channels those are as well.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hi, Deepak. To start with the mobile monetization, indeed, again, year-on-year RPS growth on mobile monetization. As bid downs -- the partner bid-downs did have an impact on mobile as well but we were still able to grow revenue per shopper year-over-
componenttext: Yes. Hi, Deepak. To start with the mobile monetization, indeed, again, year-on-year RPS growth on mobile monetization. As bid downs -- the partner bid-downs did have an impact on mobile as well but we were still able to grow revenue per shopper year-over-year. And the cause of that is the continued focus from our product teams on mobile and mobile monetization. It's been a big push for us in parallel to all the other initiatives that we have going on. Particularly on mobile web, we've seen very impressive wins. As you know, in Q2, we kicked off a new site experience, which was across desktop and mobile, and we were happy to have seen very nice wins on the mobile side. On the marketing budget and how we have seen it, can you restate the question? I don't have the full question.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes,. Sure. I was trying to figure out what channels you have pulled back and how should we think about the scope of the program going forward in 2018. I know you called out certain less efficient channels. I was wondering if it's SEM-related or retargeti
componenttext: Yes,. Sure. I was trying to figure out what channels you have pulled back and how should we think about the scope of the program going forward in 2018. I know you called out certain less efficient channels. I was wondering if it's SEM-related or retargeting or a combination of both.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you. Thanks for specifying. It's across a number of different channels. So it's not a specific channel that we've identified. We've become a little bit more sophisticated in the attribution of our different channels to the downstream booking. W
componenttext: Yes. Thank you. Thanks for specifying. It's across a number of different channels. So it's not a specific channel that we've identified. We've become a little bit more sophisticated in the attribution of our different channels to the downstream booking. We have, as you know, managed the whole portfolio of performance-based marketing more or less to break even. But if you dig deeper, there are some less efficient spend across multiple channels. And so we've been pulling back on that versus what we have planned initially in the year, which is a further impact on our revenue growth. We do believe there is more scope for efficiency optimization in our paid marketing. We continue to do that. We are continuing to doing that in Q4. And going into the next year, we do see further scope for more efficiency on that -- on the performance-based channel.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Naved Khan of SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Naved Khan of SunTrust.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions. Just wanted to clarify this but the fact that you pulled back on some of the performance at channels, is that having a more pronounced effect on desktop traffic versus mobile? And then I have a follow-up.
componenttext: Couple of questions. Just wanted to clarify this but the fact that you pulled back on some of the performance at channels, is that having a more pronounced effect on desktop traffic versus mobile? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hi, Naved. Good morning. It indeed has had a disproportionate effect on desktop. Our ability to spend on performance-based marketing is a direct function of the revenue per shopper that we can achieve. And as we discussed, we saw pressure on revenue per s
componenttext: Hi, Naved. Good morning. It indeed has had a disproportionate effect on desktop. Our ability to spend on performance-based marketing is a direct function of the revenue per shopper that we can achieve. And as we discussed, we saw pressure on revenue per shopper in desktop but we were able to increase revenue per shopper on mobile. So the relative impact has been more significant on desktop.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the -- can you just comment on the dynamics between the partners might be looking for higher ROI or might they move their ROI targets and then the advertising revenue. And at the same time you are able to improve some of the monetiz
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the -- can you just comment on the dynamics between the partners might be looking for higher ROI or might they move their ROI targets and then the advertising revenue. And at the same time you are able to improve some of the monetization on mobile hotel shopper. What's the interplay between the 2 in terms of when advertisers are bidding at different targets and then when you're also solving for increasing monetization?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Being able to improve monetization is, of course, a plus. It allows us to lean into paid marketing, be more competitive either on Google or with retargeting. And so despite partner bid-downs, our improvements there allow us to expand marketing spend
componenttext: Yes. Being able to improve monetization is, of course, a plus. It allows us to lean into paid marketing, be more competitive either on Google or with retargeting. And so despite partner bid-downs, our improvements there allow us to expand marketing spend in mobile.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark May of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark May of Citi.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: In terms of -- sorry if these have been addressed already, but in terms of the advertiser bid-downs, are there any signs of source stability there? Or are there potential for those to keep adjusting? And then will the decrease in revenue per shopper in an
componenttext: In terms of -- sorry if these have been addressed already, but in terms of the advertiser bid-downs, are there any signs of source stability there? Or are there potential for those to keep adjusting? And then will the decrease in revenue per shopper in any way impact your thinking about your marketing plans and increase in marketing spend including kind of TV going forward?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hi, Mark. Good morning. This is Steve. With regard to the bid-downs, we've run this auction for so many years. There's always a fair amount of volatility month to month or quarter-to-quarter. In this particular case, I've seen -- I think you've seen some
componenttext: Hi, Mark. Good morning. This is Steve. With regard to the bid-downs, we've run this auction for so many years. There's always a fair amount of volatility month to month or quarter-to-quarter. In this particular case, I've seen -- I think you've seen some of our partners comment on increasing marketing efficiencies and they don't seem to be publicly commenting on an ever-declining direction, but rather, they've tightened their efficiency to afford to do some other things which presumably makes sense for their business model. So as we've always done, we'll take into account the new landscape and we forecast our future plans based upon a status quo of the current bid levels.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: To your second question, Mark, revenue per shopper and the impact on marketing, broadly defined, so 2 things I'd like to highlight. So our revenue per shopper year-on-year was negative 11%. We bid separately for traffic on desktop and on mobile. The total
componenttext: To your second question, Mark, revenue per shopper and the impact on marketing, broadly defined, so 2 things I'd like to highlight. So our revenue per shopper year-on-year was negative 11%. We bid separately for traffic on desktop and on mobile. The total was down 11%. Mobile RPS was up. Desktop was down but actually less down than the 11%. So the 11% is, to a significant degree, also driven by the mix shift between the lower monetizing mobile traffic. So in the meantime, we are improving our product quite significantly. One of the things that we called out is that when we look at in the quarter, the year on year performance of the -- just the economic value the underlying leads bring that we provide to our partners, that has been improving. So the decline that we've seen on desktop revenue per shopper has been largely driven by these partner bid-downs. So while these partner bid-downs have happened, we've also made significant strides in positive development. And as we think about our marketing budget, the performance-based marketing budget and, to some extent, the TV budget as well, as we look at ROAS, ROAS is going to be impacted by our projections for revenue per shopper and our projections for revenue per shopper are a fraction of what we expect an external environment does, obviously, what our -- how our partners behave but also what we believe we can improve over time in terms of the underlying economic value of our shoppers.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Olson of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Olson of Piper Jaffray.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have a fairly high-level question. I think parts of this have already been asked in different ways. It may be hard for you to say but what do you think changed in how your major advertiser partners are thinking about the meta search channel as a source
componenttext: I have a fairly high-level question. I think parts of this have already been asked in different ways. It may be hard for you to say but what do you think changed in how your major advertiser partners are thinking about the meta search channel as a source of traffic? Did the ROI or conversion of the traffic that meta provides worsen? Or is that their ROI thresholds are higher than they were in the past? And then other than meta channel sources finding ways to deliver higher converting traffic, what could alter that trend?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Thanks. This is Steve. I would not like kind of lump all of our partners into the ones that have -- that are currently looking for higher ROI, and the partners that have had the chance to speak to are all quite appreciative and interested in b
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Thanks. This is Steve. I would not like kind of lump all of our partners into the ones that have -- that are currently looking for higher ROI, and the partners that have had the chance to speak to are all quite appreciative and interested in buying more and more traffic on the part of TripAdvisor. So I think we are an excellent partner for our hotel in OTA clients. We provide a very flexible bid mechanism, a flexible downstream kind of conversion funnel for them. And when we are able to measure the lead, the quality of the clicks that we send down to our partners, they have become more effective, in other words, they convert better than they did before, and that's direct work on our side to better qualify the traveler to be ready to book this hotel before we send them downstream to a hotel or an OTA. So we're kind of doing all the things that we can on our side to make ourselves a better partner. And I don't detect any reluctance on the part of partner hotels or OTAs to invest in the meta channel in general. And so again, you should, of course, be asking them. But when it comes to the overall health of meta as a channel, it still serves a very important function for travelers, and OTAs and hotels still recognize that. It's a very important channel for them to tap into the type of demand that we bring to the table.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Justin Patterson of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Justin Patterson of Raymond James.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: In the prepared remarks, you mentioned that Hotel segment expenses were effectively flat x TV advertising. How do you think about the trade-off between revenue growth and profitability? Do you worry that you're underinvesting in tech and content and perha
componenttext: In the prepared remarks, you mentioned that Hotel segment expenses were effectively flat x TV advertising. How do you think about the trade-off between revenue growth and profitability? Do you worry that you're underinvesting in tech and content and perhaps slowing the rate of innovation? And then secondly on the Vacation Rentals, the OTAs are stepping up their investment, and Airbnb continues to execute well. How does that shape your strategy in the segment going forward? Why not apply a meta model to vacation rental and potentially capture some of that advertising budget of the OTAs and Airbnb?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hey, Justin. This is Ernst. Indeed, the year-on-year in the third quarter, our expenses in hotel were flat other than for additional TV expenditure. We're striking a balance. We're striking a balance between, on the one hand, investing enough for growth,
componenttext: Hey, Justin. This is Ernst. Indeed, the year-on-year in the third quarter, our expenses in hotel were flat other than for additional TV expenditure. We're striking a balance. We're striking a balance between, on the one hand, investing enough for growth, on the other hand, adjust to the headwinds that we are encountering. So we're actively striking that balance between revenue growth and EBITDA. We don't believe we're underinvesting in tech and content. If you look at what we've been doing over the last year, we've made some substantial investments in the product, both on desktop and on mobile -- on desktop and mobile to get ready for our brand campaign and our focus on price comparison as a key value proposition for our users, and on mobile just to make sure that we keep improving that monetization. So we believe we have an appropriate level of investment there, and we're balancing future expense growth against our bottom line objectives as well.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. I'll take the second question. On Vacation Rentals, so from our perspective, we're really able to make sure that, that alternative launching categories were represented on TripAdvisor. So we have about 800,000 properties. That's a pretty da
componenttext: This is Steve. I'll take the second question. On Vacation Rentals, so from our perspective, we're really able to make sure that, that alternative launching categories were represented on TripAdvisor. So we have about 800,000 properties. That's a pretty darn good mix. Having said that, of course, we're open to change as well. We'd love to have even more than that and more different types available globally. To the question of why not a meta, I'm not sure that consumers are looking for the price comparison feature within a particular property more than the ability to find the widest range of properties, and that's why we do continue to grow our supply while making sure everything that's on our site is of high quality. So again, I think it's fair to say that it's important for our travelers. It doesn't have to be -- and we're making no claims that we will become bigger than some of the other guys but it does aid, clearly, our travelers' desire to have that alternative lodging choice on our site.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question is comes from Jed Kelly of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is comes from Jed Kelly of Oppenheimer.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can you talk to some of the engagement trends that you believe are benefiting from television advertising in terms of customer data such as store credit cards or repeat hotel shopper trends?
componenttext: Can you talk to some of the engagement trends that you believe are benefiting from television advertising in terms of customer data such as store credit cards or repeat hotel shopper trends?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Steve. I mean the best things we see from the TV ad relate to how many people are searching for TripAdvisor, when they come to TripAdvisor, how we see their behavior being more what we're looking for than kind of our, on average customers. S
componenttext: Sure. This is Steve. I mean the best things we see from the TV ad relate to how many people are searching for TripAdvisor, when they come to TripAdvisor, how we see their behavior being more what we're looking for than kind of our, on average customers. So when they come and they've seen the TV ad, they're more likely to book. They're more likely to go through the hotel shopping experience and actually consummate the transaction either on TripAdvisor or downstream on our client sites. So the goal to remind folks about the TV was really to present TripAdvisor as a place where not only can you read reviews, but you can do your price comparison research and understand how TripAdvisor can save you money by not, to the specific of your question, to help us generate more Instant Bookings whereby we might be able to have a credit card but to really change the perception. So I couldn't honestly tell you right now whether we are generating more save credit cards or something like from the TV campaign because it really wasn't the target of our branding exercise.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Nate Schindler of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Nate Schindler of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: You obviously have 2 large OTA partners who are your principal revenue source in your click-based revenue business. And from the discussion review and a discussion with a competitor, it's pretty clear that one of them has changed their philosophy on ROI.
componenttext: You obviously have 2 large OTA partners who are your principal revenue source in your click-based revenue business. And from the discussion review and a discussion with a competitor, it's pretty clear that one of them has changed their philosophy on ROI. How does that affect the other?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Steve, Nate. We run an auction. There's 2 big players up there. With the 2 big players, of course, there are several brands to compete there. Where anyone player feeds down, by mathematical definition, the share shifts to the other players i
componenttext: Sure. This is Steve, Nate. We run an auction. There's 2 big players up there. With the 2 big players, of course, there are several brands to compete there. Where anyone player feeds down, by mathematical definition, the share shifts to the other players in the auction. So if you don't have any, you don't know.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Not just though on share. How does it affect their behavior, are they are lowering their bids? Do they fall bids lower or do they just simply get more share at the same bid?
componenttext: Not just though on share. How does it affect their behavior, are they are lowering their bids? Do they fall bids lower or do they just simply get more share at the same bid?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: You'd have to look kind of market by market. What am I trying to say? When a single player changes their bids, it's in aggregate. So it's somewhat difficult for another partner to know exactly what they can and cannot do in response. So you should think o
componenttext: You'd have to look kind of market by market. What am I trying to say? When a single player changes their bids, it's in aggregate. So it's somewhat difficult for another partner to know exactly what they can and cannot do in response. So you should think of it is as share shift, yes, but I wouldn't think of necessarily a big corresponding change on the part of the other client.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: And just one other clarification. You mentioned that it's individual brands within these companies. Is the partner that has changed their ROI philosophy, are they doing it across their brands, at a corporate level? Or do they do it on a specific brand in
componenttext: And just one other clarification. You mentioned that it's individual brands within these companies. Is the partner that has changed their ROI philosophy, are they doing it across their brands, at a corporate level? Or do they do it on a specific brand in a specific region?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I appreciate the question, but we really aren't able to talk about specific brands in our discussions.
componenttext: Yes. I appreciate the question, but we really aren't able to talk about specific brands in our discussions.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Bieber of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Bieber of Crédit Suisse.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could help us some size the components of the non-Hotel business. Obviously, there's Vacation Rental, Restaurants and Attractions in there. Can you just give us some context for the relative size of those businesses and growth rates?
componenttext: I was hoping you could help us some size the components of the non-Hotel business. Obviously, there's Vacation Rental, Restaurants and Attractions in there. Can you just give us some context for the relative size of those businesses and growth rates?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of growth rates, clearly, the faster growers are Attractions and Restaurants. So in terms of growth, they're driving the growth in the segment. In terms of relative sizes, I don't want to be too specific in breaking it out because we haven't
componenttext: Yes. In terms of growth rates, clearly, the faster growers are Attractions and Restaurants. So in terms of growth, they're driving the growth in the segment. In terms of relative sizes, I don't want to be too specific in breaking it out because we haven't broken it out, but Attractions is the largest of the 3 components, with the other 2 smaller. But that's the order of magnitude but I'm not going to go in more detail in breaking that as a percentage.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Brian Fitzgerald of Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Brian Fitzgerald of Jefferies.

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: We want to know what type of dynamic if there's anything notable to call out with respect to conversion of non-Hotel from Hotel. Are you seeing any uplift or tailwinds in the non-Hotel area where branded campaigns are running? And then a follow-up on non-
componenttext: We want to know what type of dynamic if there's anything notable to call out with respect to conversion of non-Hotel from Hotel. Are you seeing any uplift or tailwinds in the non-Hotel area where branded campaigns are running? And then a follow-up on non-Hotel type of inventory. How do you feel about the breadth and depth of what you have there, of your offering there and then the rate at which you're adding more inventory, if you will, there?

headline: TripAdvisor, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. This is Steve. That TV campaign is very much focused around educating folks around price comparisons around hotels. Looking at a conversion lift in the non-Hotel category from the initial brand awareness, next to impossible for us to tell i
componenttext: Thanks, Brian. This is Steve. That TV campaign is very much focused around educating folks around price comparisons around hotels. Looking at a conversion lift in the non-Hotel category from the initial brand awareness, next to impossible for us to tell in part because those components on TripAdvisor are growing so strong all by themselves. So we just have a lot of goodness happening in that Attraction Restaurant category. In terms of non-Hotel inventory trends, we continue to grow both on Restaurants and Attractions in particular. And Attractions, the bookable products, up 30-plus-percent year-on-year. The overall Attractions listing growing as well. And when you look back a couple of years, the bookable supply is up 5x or something. So the marketplace concept has really worked for us. We continue to grow in all regions of the world and we love it. It's the classic marketplace model where as we had more of the supply batch to the TripAdvisor demand that we already have, it continues to grow. I think our TripAdvisor sourced bookings for the Attraction category is -- was up 100% year-on-year in Q3. So we're just seeing really nice signs of that whole trip lifecycle coming in together, and you see that in the numbers, in that other Hotel business growth. So Ernst, do you want to add anything? I think we're good, though. Thanks
